hints_html:
Remember that all vectors lying in the tangent plane to \(z = f(x,y)\) are perpendicular to the normal vector to the surface at the same point. I.e., let \((x,y,z) = (x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})\) be a point on the surface of \(z = f(x,y)\). If \(\mathbf{n}\) is the normal vector to \(z = f(x,y)\) at this point, then

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n}\cdot \mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0}, \quad \mbox{where} \quad \mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} x - x_{0} \\ y - y_{0} \\ z - z_{0}\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

gives the equation of the tangent plane to the surface at the point \((x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})\).

In this case, the normal vector, \(\mathbf{n}\), is determined by the gradient of function \(F(x,y,z) = f(x,y) - z = 0\):

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n} = \nabla F(x,y,z) = \begin{bmatrix}f_{x}(x,y) \\ f_{y}(x,y) \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
The equation of the tangent plane is given by evaluating

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n}\cdot\mathbf{v} = 0\end{aligned}\]

where \(\mathbf{v} = [x - 2, y - 1, z - f(2,1)]^{T}\) and \(\mathbf{n}\) is a normal vector to the surface \(z = f(x,y)\) at \((x,y) = (2,1)\). The normal vector at the point \((x,y)\) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n}(x,y) = \begin{bmatrix}f_{x}(x,y) \\ f_{y}(x,y) \\ -1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -2x e^{-x^2+4y^2} \\ 8y e^{-x^2+4y^2} \\ -1\end{bmatrix} \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathbf{n}(2,1) = \begin{bmatrix} -4 \\ 8 \\ -1\end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Evaluating \(\mathbf{n}\cdot\mathbf{v} = 0\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n}\cdot\mathbf{v} = -4(x - 2) + 8(y - 1) -1(z - 1) = 0.\end{aligned}\]

We simplify the above equation (although it is not necessary) and get the tangent plane to \(f(x,y)\) at \((2,1)\):

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue} -4x + 8y - z = -1.}\end{aligned}\]

We can also get the tangent plane by using a linear Taylor approximation. Recall for a function \(\displaystyle {}f(x,y)\) we have the linear approximation at a point \(\displaystyle {}(x_0,y_0)\) is

\[\begin{aligned} f(x,y)\approx{}f(x_0,y_0)+\frac{\partial{}f}{\partial{}x}(x_0,y_0)(x-x_0)+\frac{\partial{}f}{\partial{}y}(x_0,y_0)(y-y_0).\end{aligned}\]

We are given that we want to approximate \(\displaystyle {}f(2,1)\) and so \(\displaystyle {}x_0=2\) and \(\displaystyle {}y_0=1\). We have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial{}f}{\partial{}x}&=-2x\textrm{e}^{-x^2+4y^2}\\ \frac{\partial{}f}{\partial{}y}&=8y\textrm{e}^{-x^2+4y^2}\end{aligned}\]

and so

\[\begin{aligned} f(2,1)&=1\\ \frac{\partial{}f}{\partial{}x}(2,1)&=-4\\ \frac{\partial{}f}{\partial{}y}(2,1)&=8.\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\displaystyle {}z=f(x,y)\) we have

\[\begin{aligned} z&=1-4(x-2)+8(y-1)\\ 0&=-4(x-2)+8(y-1)-(z-1)\end{aligned}\]

as the tangent plane approximation at the desired point.

statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x,y) = e^{-x^{2} + 4y^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

b) Find the equation of the tangent plane to the graph \(z = f(x,y)\) at the point where \((x,y) = (2,1)\).
